ai-mn67:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Cātumā in a myrobalan grove.
ai-mn67:2.1_0: Now at that time around five hundred mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Cātumā to see the Buddha.
ai-mn67:2.2_0: And the visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.
ai-mn67:3.1_0: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-mn67:3.2_0: “Ānanda, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ai-mn67:3.3_0: And Ānanda told him what had happened.
ai-mn67:3.4_0: It’s those visiting mendicants who, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.”
ai-mn67:4.1_0: “Now then, Ānanda, with my word address those monks, (saying):
ai-mn67:4.3_0: “Yes, Sir.” He replied, and did as he was asked.
ai-mn67:4.3_1: and after going, he said this to those monks:
ai-mn67:4.5_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn67:4.5_2: They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,
ai-mn67:4.6_0: “Mendicants, what’s with that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
ai-mn67:4.7_0: And they told him what had happened.
ai-mn67:4.8_0: It’s these visiting mendicants who, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.”
ai-mn67:5.1_0: “Go away, mendicants, I dismiss you. You are not to stay in my presence.”
ai-mn67:5.2_0: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. They got up from their seats, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. They set their lodgings in order and left, taking their bowls and robes.
ai-mn67:6.1_0: Now at that time the Sakyans of Cātumā were sitting together at the meeting hall on some business.
ai-mn67:6.3_0: They went up to them and said,
ai-mn67:6.5_0: “Sirs, the mendicant Saṅgha has been dismissed by the Buddha.”
ai-mn67:6.6_0: “Well then, may we sit for a short time! Hopefully we will have confidence in the Buddha.”
ai-mn67:7.1_0: Then the Sakyans of Cātumā went to the Fortunate One,
ai-mn67:7.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn67:7.1_2: While sitting on one side the Sakyans of Cātumā said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn67:7.2_0: “May the Buddha approve of the mendicant Saṅgha!
ai-mn67:7.3_0: May the Buddha approve of the mendicant Saṅgha!
ai-mn67:7.4_0: Just as the mendicant Saṅgha has did in the past.
ai-mn67:7.4_1: so may the Fortunate One consent to the Community of monks,
ai-mn67:7.5_0: There are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training.
ai-mn67:7.6_0: If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
ai-mn67:7.7_0: If young seedlings don’t get water they may change and fall apart. ...
ai-mn67:7.8_0: In the same way, there are mendicants here who are junior, recently gone forth, newly come to this teaching and training. If they don’t get to see the Buddha they may change and fall apart.
ai-mn67:7.9_0: If a young calf doesn’t see its mother it may change and fall apart.

ai-mn67:10.1_0: The Sakyans of Cātumā and Brahmā Sahampati were able to restore the Buddha’s confidence with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.
ai-mn67:11.1_0: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn67:11.2_0: “Get up, reverends, and pick up your bowls and robes.
ai-mn67:11.3_0: The Buddha’s confidence has been restored by the Sakyans of Cātumā and Brahmā Sahampati with the similes of the seedlings and the calf.”
ai-mn67:12.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn67:12.2_0: “Sāriputta, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”
ai-mn67:12.4_0: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn67:12.5_0: Now we will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life. Meanwhile, there will be no more lives.’”
ai-mn67:13.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,
ai-mn67:13.2_0: “Moggallāna, what did you think when the mendicant Saṅgha was dismissed by me?”
ai-mn67:13.4_0: ‘The Buddha has dismissed the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-mn67:13.5_0: Now he will remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life. Meanwhile, Venerable Sāriputta and I will lead the mendicant Saṅgha.’”
ai-mn67:13.7_0: For either I should lead the mendicant Saṅgha, or else Sāriputta and Moggallāna.”
ai-mn67:14.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-mn67:14.2_0: “Mendicants, when you go into the water you should anticipate four dangers.
ai-mn67:14.4_0: The dangers of waves, crocodiles, whirlpools, and sharks.
ai-mn67:14.5_0: These are the four dangers that anyone who enters the water should anticipate.
ai-mn67:15.1_0: In the same way, a gentleman who goes forth from the lay life to homelessness in this teaching and training should anticipate four dangers.
